title: Jeu de mail
text:
' or ' (<a href="Middle%20French">Middle French</a> for 'mallet game', or sometimes interpreted as 'straw game') is a now-obsolete <a href="lawn%20game">lawn game</a> originating in the <a href="Late%20Middle%20Ages">Late Middle Ages</a> and mostly played in France, surviving in some locales into the 20th century. It is a form of <a href="ground%20billiards">ground billiards</a>, using one or more <a href="ball">ball</a>s, a stick with a <a href="mallet">mallet</a>-like head, and usually featuring one or more targets such as hoops or holes. "" was ancestral to the games <a href="golf">golf</a>, <a href="palle-malle">palle-malle</a> and <a href="croquet">croquet</a>, and (by moving it indoors and playing on a table with smaller equipment), <a href="Cue%20sports">billiards</a>.
History.
The first known written record of "" is a <a href="Renaissance%20Latin">Renaissance Latin</a> text dating to 1416. The in the name probably means '<a href="Post%20maul">maul</a>, <a href="mallet">mallet</a>', from <a href="Latin%20language">Latin</a> . An alternative meaning of 'straw' has been suggested (<a href="Modern%20French">Modern French</a> ), on the basis that the target hoops used in some versions of the game were sometimes made of bound straw.
Quite popular in various forms in France and Italy in the <a href="Late%20Middle%20Ages">Late Middle Ages</a> and <a href="Renaissance">Renaissance</a>, the game developed into <a href="pall-mall">pall-mall</a> in the <a href="early%20modern%20period">early modern period</a>, which spread to <a href="Scotland">Scotland</a> then <a href="England">England</a>; this, in turn, eventually led to <a href="croquet">croquet</a>.
According to <a href="Pierre%20de%20Bourdeille%2C%20seigneur%20de%20Brant%C3%B4me">Brantôme</a>, King <a href="Henry%20II%20of%20France">Henry II of France</a> (ruled 1547–1559) was an excellent player of and (a form of that eventually developed into <a href="tennis">tennis</a> and other <a href="racquet%20sport">racquet sport</a>s). <a href="Louis%20XIV%20of%20France">Louis XIV</a> (ruled 1661–1715), who hated , was on the other hand enthusiastic about , and the playing court in the gardens of <a href="Tuileries%20Palace">Tuileries Palace</a> was enlarged during his reign.
The game was still played in France, in the areas of <a href="Montpellier">Montpellier</a> and <a href="Aix-en-Provence">Aix-en-Provence</a>, into the early 20th century, before the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a>. An educational institution in Montpellier, <a href="Coll%C3%A8ge%20Jeu%20de%20Mail">Collège Jeu de Mail</a>, still bears the name of this game.
Game play.
The game makes use of one or more balls that are generally of <a href="Buxus%20sempervirens">boxwood</a>, but higher-quality balls are of <a href="medlar">medlar</a>. The ball is struck with a long stick with a mallet- or <a href="foot">foot</a>-like end, similar to a croquet mallet or <a href="Golf%20club%20%28equipment%29">golf club</a>, respectively; it is essentially a heavy version of the <a href="Cue%20sports">billiard</a> (which eventually developed into the <a href="cue%20stick">cue stick</a>). Different variants of the game may have differing goals or targets (if any), ranging from croquet-like hoops to golf-like holes in the ground.
